{{Refimprove|date=October 2010}} '''Oberon Press''' is an independent [[Canada|Canadian]] literary [[publisher]] founded in 1966.<ref>[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com Canadian Encyclopedia]</ref> It focuses mainly on Canadian [[fiction]]—particularly short stories—and [[poetry]], but also publishes [[criticism]], [[history]], [[biography]] and [[autobiography]].<ref name="website">[http://www.oberonpress.ca Oberon Press web site]</ref>
Oberon has published early work by Canadian writers such as [[David Adams Richards]], [[Wayne Johnston (writer)|Wayne Johnston]], [[Peter Behrens]], [[Hugh Hood]], [[David Helwig]], [[bpNichol]], [[George Bowering]] and [[W.P. Kinsella]].<ref name="website"/> Two short-story anthologies, ''Best Canadian Stories'' and ''Coming Attractions'', feature the work of established and new Canadian writers. Oberon’s national restaurant guide, ''Where to Eat in Canada'', published annually since 1971, has sold more than 150,000 copies.<ref name="website"/>
The ''Best Canadian Stories'' anthology, now in its fortieth edition, has been edited by [[David Helwig]], [[John Metcalf (writer)|John Metcalf]], [[Clark Blaise]], [[Leon Rooke]] and [[Douglas Glover (writer)|Douglas Glover]], and features the best stories of the preceding year. ''Coming Attractions'', which introduces previously unpublished writers, has appeared annually since 1980. Writers published in ''Coming Attractions'' include [[Rohinton Mistry]], [[Frances Itani]], [[Lisa Moore (writer)|Lisa Moore]], [[Dennis Bock]], [[Neil Smith (writer)|Neil Smith]], [[Timothy Taylor (writer)|Timothy Taylor]], [[Bonnie Burnard]], [[Sharon Butala]], [[Steven Heighton]], [[Caroline Adderson]] and [[Rebecca Rosenblum]].<ref name="website"/><ref>Smith, S. (1997, January). Book Review: ''Coming Attractions 96''. Toronto: ''Quill & Quire''</ref>
Oberon published eight new titles in 2010, and now has 664 titles in print in 1216 editions.<ref name="website"/> Many of Oberon’s books are [[typeset]] in the company’s own printshop, using traditional [[hot metal typesetting|hot-metal techniques]]. The books are printed on [[acid-free paper]] on a sheet-fed [[offset printing]] press.
Michael Macklem, the founder and president of Oberon, was awarded the [[Order of Canada]] in 2006 in recognition of his work with the press.<ref>[http://www.trinity.utoronto.ca/News_Events/e-Trinity/1-2-marg.htm University of Toronto - Trinity College web site]</ref>

{{Infobox organization |type = [[Non-profit]] |services = [[Sex workers' rights]] |founder = [[Audacia Ray]] |founded = {{start date and age|2010}} |named_after = [[International Day to End Violence Against Sex Workers|Red Umbrella Protest]] |location = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. }}
The '''Red Umbrella Project''' is a [[New York City|New York]] based [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit organization]] that advocates on behalf of [[sex worker]]s and strives to empower them by giving them a voice.
== History == The Red Umbrella Project was founded in 2010 by writer and activist [[Audacia Ray]]. As a former sex worker, Ray witnessed first-hand the [[discrimination]] against sex workers by police and society. Ray envisioned an organization where sex workers could come together to share their stories, advocate for change and help one another. She chose the name The Red Umbrella Project because in 2001 during the 49th Venice Biennale of Art in [[Venice|Venice, Italy]], sex workers demonstrated against inhumane work conditions and [[human rights violation]] by holding up [[International Day to End Violence Against Sex Workers|red umbrellas]], making this a symbol of resistance to discrimination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sexworkeurope.org/campaigns/red-umbrella-campaigns|title=Under the Red Umbrella {{!}} Sex Work Europe|website=www.sexworkeurope.org|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref>
In 2009 Ray started hosting storytelling events for sex workers at the Happy Ending Lounge on New York's Lower East Side. The goals of these workshops and storytelling events were to shine light and empower sex workers, but it soon became apparent that these sex workers shared several common burdens. Many identified as [[Transgender|trans]] or [[queer]],<ref name=":2" /> there was an alarming rate of [[HIV/AIDS]] cases among them,<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/trans-sex-workers-are-25-times-more-likely-to-be-hiv-positive-than-the-general-population/|title=Trans Sex Workers Are 25 Times More Likely to Be HIV Positive Than the General Population|newspaper=The Nation|issn=0027-8378|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref> they feared carrying condoms due to the criminalization of condoms,<ref name=":3" /> and most of all they were tossed aside and mistreated by most of society, when all they were doing is trying to make a living and find economic opportunity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2016/03/sex-workers-legalization-c-v-r.html|title=Is Prostitution Just Another Job?|last=|first=|date=2016-03-21|work=|newspaper=New York Magazine|access-date=2016-12-20|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/08/nyregion/08bodies.html|title=Prostitute Disappearances Unnoticed Until Bodies Were Found|last=Fernandez|first=Manny|date=2011-04-07|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
== Advocacy issues ==
=== Sex-worker diversion programs === In 2014 New York City created a series of special courts for sex workers arrested on prostitution-related charges. The new courts, known as [[Human trafficking|Human Trafficking]] Intervention Courts (HTIC),<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/01/12/sex-trafficking-victims-not-prostitutes-finally-getting-help-and-a-new-name-in-court.html|title=Sex Trafficking Victims, Not 'Prostitutes,' Finally Getting Help (and a New Name) in Court|last=Ungar-Sargon|first=Batya|date=2015-01-12|newspaper=The Daily Beast|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref> treated all sex workers as human trafficking victims, and through a variety of [[bullying]] tactics forced defendants to forgo their [[constitutional right]] of a [[Jury trial|trial by jury]] and agree to a [[plea bargain]] of a sex worker diversion program which consisted of a court mandated treatment program, followed by [[adjournment in contemplation of dismissal]] (ACD).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/why-are-new-york-courts-lumping-in-sex-workers-with-the-victims-of-human-trafficking-6680891|title=Why Are New York Courts Lumping in Sex Workers With the Victims of Human Trafficking?|last=Merlan|first=Anna|date=2014-10-01|newspaper=Village Voice|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref> The Red Umbrella Project argued that the city's intentions were good and that the new court does help people who are forced into sex work.<ref name=":1" /> However, the court still treats the sex workers like criminals <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/sex-workers-and-the-city-0000550-v22n1|title=Special Prostitution Courts and the Myth of 'Rescuing' Sex Workers - VICE|website=Vice|language=en-us|access-date=2016-12-20|date=2015-01-05}}</ref> and makes the assumption that all sex workers are victims of human trafficking and that no one does sex work out of free will, for their personal economic gain. There may also be assumed [[Workplace discrimination|discrimination within the workforce]] due to the fact that many sex workers are of [[Person of color|color,]] queer or trans. The counseling and assistance offered through the court mandated treatment program provides them with no way of economic opportunity other than sex work. The Red Umbrella Project wants to see the sex-worker diversion program restructured with an emphasis on [[economic empowerment]] through job training and economic opportunities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/why-do-sex-work-diversion-programs-fail/|title=Why Do Sex-Work Diversion Programs Fail?|newspaper=The Nation|issn=0027-8378|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.vice.com/article/not-everyone-is-happy-with-the-ny-courts-treating-sex-workers-as-trafficking-victims|title=Not Everyone Is Happy with the NY Courts Treating Sex Workers as Trafficking Victims {{!}} VICE News|newspaper=VICE News|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/opinion/gira-grant-flawed-justice-sex-workers-article-1.1958688?cid=bitly|title=Gira Grant: Flawed justice for sex workers|newspaper=NY Daily News|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
=== HIV/AIDS and trans health disparity === The Red Umbrella Project along with the Nation Center for Transgender Equality (NCTE) and Best Practices Policy Project (BPPP) published a report that [[transgender]] people in the sex trade are twelve times more likely to be living with HIV/AIDS than transgender people who were never involved in the sex trade and twenty-five times more likely to be living with HIV/AIDS than the general population. The Red Umbrella Project points to the fear of [[condom]]s as being used as evidence of prostitution along with [[Racial profiling|profiling of race]] and [[Gender policing|gender]] by police officers where: "Women and trans people having condoms on them is criminalized, whereas a white [[Cisgender|cis male]] having condoms on him is looked at as safe-sex practice." <ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://inthesetimes.com/working/entry/13553/Criminalizing_Condoms_Sex_Workers_Get_Policed_but_Remain_Unprotected|title=Criminalizing Condoms: Sex Workers Get Policed but Remain Unprotected|last=Chen|first=Michelle|date=2012-07-20|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
The Red Umbrella Project and other advocacy groups have been able to push for reform in heavily [[Liberalism|liberal]] cities such as New York City, [[San Francisco]] and [[Washington, D.C.]], <ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-nypd-condoms-20140513-story.html|title=NYPD limits use of condoms seized from sex workers as evidence|last=Susman|first=Tine|date=2014-05-12|work=|publisher=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2016-12-20|via=}}</ref> but other more [[Conservatism|conservative]] cities such as [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]] use condoms as evidence as part of their anti-prostitution campaign Project Rose.<ref name=":2" />
== The Red Umbrella Diaries == [[File:Nahshon and Audacia Ray.jpg|thumb|Nahshon Dion Anderson and Audacia Ray founder of Red Umbrella Project.]] The Red Umbrella Diaries started as a monthly story-telling event at the Happy Ending Lounge on New York's Lower East Side that sought to shed the [[Social stigma|stigma]] around sex work, make it less isolating and show that it can be both [[Exploitation of labour|exploitative]] and empowering" at the same time. The Red Umbrella Diaries was listed by ''[[The Village Voice]]'' as "The Best Way to Meet Sex Workers (for Free)",<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/news/new-documentary-aims-to-complicate-the-narrative-about-sex-workers-7885128|title=New Documentary Aims to 'Complicate the Narrative' About Sex Workers|last=Margolin|first=Madison|date=2015-11-10|newspaper=Village Voice|access-date=2016-12-19}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/best-of/2010/sports-and-recreation/best-way-to-meet-sex-workers-for-free-6449197|title=Best Way to Meet Sex Workers (for Free): Red Umbrella Diaries {{!}} Best of NYC® 2010: Your Key to the City|website=Village Voice|access-date=2016-12-19 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20170510170711/http://www.villagevoice.com/best-of/2010/sports-and-recreation/best-way-to-meet-sex-workers-for-free-6449197 |archive-date=10 May 2017}}</ref> and was listed as "Best of New York City's Sports and Recreation" in 2010.<ref name=":0" />
The monthly event eventually led to a documentary produced by [[Audacia Ray]] and multi-[[Emmy Award]]-Winning director David Kornfield and funded by the Red Umbrella Project. The documentary featured seven sex workers telling their stories about trading money for sex on the streets of New York City. The documentary premiered at the [[Portland Film Festival]], in [[Portland, Oregon]] and at the [[IFC Center|IFC theater]] in New York City, and was a [[Doc NYC]] official selection.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://filmmakermagazine.com/96311-talking-sex-work-with-the-red-umbrella-diaries-producer-audacia-ray/#.WFmLxnrauUm|title=Talking Sex Work with The Red Umbrella Diaries Producer Audacia Ray {{!}} Filmmaker Magazine|last=Wissot|first=Lauren|newspaper=Filmmaker Magazine|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref>
== Memoir writing workshop == In 2012 the Red Umbrella Project started offering [[memoir]] writing workshops in New York City which was made possible in part by a grant from Poets & Writers. The peer-facilitated workshops were open to all people with experience in the [[sex trade]] and allows sex workers a safe space to build writing skills, share their stories with others, and get feedback from their peers. Attendees of the workshop have the option of having their work published in the Red Umbrella Project's biannual literary journal ''Prose & Lore'', and to share their work on stage as part of their Page to Stage workshop.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://redumbrellaproject.org/memoir/|title=Memoir Writing Workshops {{!}} Red Umbrella Project|website=redumbrellaproject.org|access-date=2016-12-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pw.org/content/melissa_petro_and_red_umbrella_writers_dispel_myths_about_sex_work?cmnt_all=1|title=Melissa Petro and Red Umbrella Writers Dispel Myths About Sex Work {{!}} Poets and Writers|website=www.pw.org|access-date=2016-12-20|date=2013-01-03}}</ref> One participant was [[Nahshon Dion Anderson|Nahshon Anderson]], who for eight weeks in 2013 workshopped the first chapter of their nonfiction manuscript Shooting Range that won a 2014 [[Bronx Recognizes Its Own Award]] (BRIO), given by the [[Bronx Council on the Arts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.arts.gov/50th/stories/nahshon-d-ratcliff|title=Nahshon D. Ratcliff {{!}} NEA|website=www.arts.gov|access-date=2016-12-20|date=2015-10-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lambdaliterary.org/interviews/09/18/amber-dawn/|title=Amber Dawn on Writing a Contemporary Ghost Story|last=Anderson|first=Nahshon Dion|date=2018-09-18|work=Lambda Literary|access-date=2018-10-31|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{Multiple issues| {{Unreferenced|date=April 2009}} {{Missing information|Traditional manufacturing methods and modern commercial manufacturing methods|date=September 2010}} }}
{{Nihongo|'''Rokushō'''|緑青}} is a traditional [[Japan|Japanese]] chemical compound used in the [[niiro]] process for artificially inducing [[patina|patination]] in decorative non-ferrous metals, especially several copper alloys, with the results being metals of the [[irogane]] class. These "colour metals," virtually unknown outside [[Japan]] until the late 19th century, have achieved some popularity in craft circles in other parts of the world since then.
==Usage== Rokushō is used to treat a number of metals, including raw natural copper, which holds impurities, purified copper, and copper alloy mixes with two to five metals, to produce irogane metals, including: [[shakudō]], an alloy of copper and gold, which becomes black to dark blue-violet; [[shibuichi]], an alloy of fine silver and copper (in a higher percentage than sterling), which turns grey to misty [[Aquamarine (color)|aquamarine]] or other shades of blue to green; [[kuromido]] which becomes dark coppery black.
Rokushō was generally used to patinate all types of [[mokume-gane]] ("wood grain metal") as well.
Although other patination agents can be used on these metals, some artisans prefer the rich colors achieved with traditional rokushō in the niiro process.
These metals are becoming increasingly popular in high-end artistic jewelry, especially in bi-metals (a layer of the alloy fused to another metal such as sterling). Because rokushō has a dramatically different effect on sterling silver than on the alloys typically fused to it in bi-metals, a common technique in art jewelry is to engrave through the alloy layer in a pattern to reveal the silver underneath prior to patination. This provides a rich contrast in color, highlighting the pattern.
==Formulation== The formulae for rokushō are not published widely or freely, but passed on in the Japanese craft tradition. However, some scholars have analysed samples of the material.
Premixed rokushō can be purchased outside Japan through specialty jewelry suppliers. Additionally, several different formulas have been proposed to replicate the traditional product for those who prefer to make their own:
* In a container made of glass, porcelain, or copper, dissolve 6g copper acetate, 2g calcium carbonate, and 2g sodium hydroxide in 150ml water. After a week, siphon or decant the clear liquid from the top; just before use, add another 2g copper sulfate.{{clarify|reason=1) text says "add another 2g copper sulfate", but this is the first instance of copper sulfate in the recipe, 2) calcium carbonate is not soluble in water|date=June 2015}} * Dissolve 4g [[copper acetate]], 1g [[copper nitrate]], 1g [[cupric chloride]], and 4g [[copper sulfate]] in 1 liter of distilled water. * Dissolve 60g copper acetate and 60g copper sulfate in a 2 liter solution of white vinegar diluted 5-12% with water.
Rokusho is not used alone, but mixed with one or more other chemicals. Further, metal to be processed is cleaned in advance of treatment, using a mild acid bath (oxalic or sulfuric acids are frequently used), scrubbing with [[daikon radish]] or pumice, and / or a surface abrasive, and often treated after patination also.
==External links== * [http://www.jimkelso.com/japanpatina.html/tutorial.htm Japanese traditional patina tutorial by crafter Jim Kelso]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rokusho}}

{{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2011}} {{Infobox MP | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Samuel Mauger | honorific-suffix = | image = Samuel Mauger 2.jpg | constituency_MP = [[Division of Melbourne Ports|Melbourne Ports]] | parliament = Australian | majority = | predecessor = ''New seat'' | successor = [[James Mathews (Australian politician)|James Mathews]] | term_start = 29 March 1901 | term_end = 12 December 1906 | constituency_MP2 = [[Division of Maribyrnong|Maribyrnong]] | parliament2 = Australian | predecessor2 = ''New seat'' | successor2 = [[James Fenton (Australian politician)|James Fenton]] | term_start2 = 12 December 1906 | term_end2 = 13 April 1910 | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1857|11|12}} | birth_place = [[Geelong]], Victoria | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1936|6|26|1857|11|12}} | death_place = [[Elsternwick]], Victoria | nationality = Australian | spouse = Hanna Rice | party = [[Protectionist Party|Protectionist]] (1901–09)
[[Commonwealth Liberal Party|Liberal]] (1909–10) | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = Hat manufacturer | profession = | religion = [[Australian Church]] | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Samuel Mauger''' (pronounced ''Major'') (12 November 1857 – 26 June 1936)John Lack, '[http://www.adb.online.anu.edu.au/biogs/A100442b.htm Mauger, Samuel (1857–1936)]', ''[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]'', Volume 10, [[Melbourne University Press|MUP]], 1986, pp 451–453. Retrieved 5 October 2009 was an Australian social reformer, hat manufacturing unionist and a [[Protectionist]] politician. ==Early life== Mauger was born in [[Geelong]], Victoria, son of immigrants from [[Guernsey]], [[Channel Islands]], Samuel Mauger Senior and Caroline ''née'' Liz who migrated to Australia in the 1850s. Mauger junior was educated at the Geelong National School, but left school early to become an errand boy for a hat maker when his father contracted rheumatic fever. Mauger later owned the hat manufacturing business. Mauger was a Bible class teacher at St Mark's [[Church of England]] in [[Fitzroy, Victoria|Fitzroy]]. He later became the Sunday-school superintendent at St Paul's Congregational Church in North Fitzroy. On 13 May 1880, Mauger married Hanna Rice who he had met at St Mark's; they eventually had four sons and four daughters. ==Career== Mauger held various memberships to various organisations. He was a superintendent in the Fire Brigades' Association of Victoria and four times president of the Metropolitan Fire Brigades Board. Mauger was one of the founders and secretary of the Anti-Sweating League from 1895. Mauger was on the Board enquiry for unemployment in 1899 and involved in the royal commission of Victorian factories and shops law in 1900. Being a devout Christian of the [[Australian Church]], Mauger was president of the [[Young Men's Christian Association]] and president of the Melbourne Total Abstinence Society. Mauger attempted to run for politics in various State electorates before becoming a Member of Parliament. He stood for the seat of [[Electoral district of Fitzroy (Victoria)|Fitzroy]] in 1892, [[Electoral district of South Melbourne|South Melbourne]] in 1896 and [[Electoral district of Portland|Portland]] in 1897. In 1899 he was a firefighter in the Melbourne suburb of Richmond.{{cite web|last=Birch|first=Adrian|title=Samuel Mauger firefighter.|url=http://handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/69174|publisher=State Library of Victoria|accessdate=25 April 2014}} In 1900, Mauger was elected to the [[Victorian Legislative Assembly]] seat of [[Electoral district of Footscray|Footscray]]. He held the seat of Footscray until May 1901, where he resigned from State politics and ran for Federal politics. Mauger was the first member for [[Division of Melbourne Ports|Melbourne Ports]] in 1901 until his defeat to [[Australian Labor Party|ALP]] candidate [[James Mathews (Australian politician)|James Mathews]] in [[Australian federal election, 1906|1906]]. Mauger then soon elected to the new Federal seat of [[Division of Maribyrnong|Maribyrnong]] and became the electorate's first Federal Member of Parliament. He was a Minister without a Portfolio from 1906 until 1907 and then [[Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Australia)|Postmaster-General]] until 1908. Mauger lost his seat of [[Division of Maribyrnong|Maribyrnong]] to [[Australian Labor Party|ALP]] candidate [[James Fenton (Australian politician)|James Fenton]] in [[Australian federal election, 1910|1910]]. Mauger ran for the Victorian Senate in 1913 and 1914, but failed to get elected.[http://psephos.adam-carr.net/countries/a/australia/candidates/m.txt Australian Federal Political Candidates (Surname beginning with letter "M")] He was an ardent protectionist and was for some time honorary secretary of the protectionists' association of Victoria; he was for a time president of the Melbourne Total Abstinence Society, and chairman of the Indeterminate Sentences Board; and he presumably found some time for his business as a hatter and mercer. For about 50 years in every movement in Melbourne intended to better the conditions of the mass of the people, Mauger was to be found working incessantly and showing much organizing ability. ==Legacy== In 1934 Mauger wrote a brochure on ''The Rise and Progress of the Metropolitan Fire Brigade, Victoria, Australia'', on page 29 some verses relating to the success of the staff fund illustrate his philosophy of life. Basically it was that if anything is brought forward for the good of humanity, difficulties will vanish if the problem is tackled with sufficient courage. Mauger died in [[Elsternwick, Victoria]] and is buried in the [[Melbourne General Cemetery]]. At his funeral, he was given a fire guard honour. Mauger was survived by his wife, two sons and four daughters.{{Dictionary of Australian Biography|First=Samuel|Last=Mauger|shortlink=0-dict-biogMa-Mo.html#mauger1|accessdate=5 October 2009}} Kim |theme_music_composer = {{plainlist| * {{nowrap|Brad Breeck}} (opening) * {{nowrap|Daron Nefcy}} & {{nowrap|[[Ego Plum]]}} (ending; seasons 1 & 2) * {{nowrap|Daron Nefcy}} & {{nowrap|Brian H. Kim}} (ending; season 3) }} |country = United States |language = English |network = [[Disney XD]] (2015–18)
[[Disney Channel]] (2018–present) |opentheme = "I'm from Another Dimension" performed{{nbsp}}by {{nowrap|Brad Breeck}} |endtheme = "Star vs. the Forces of Evil End Theme" performed{{nbsp}}by {{nowrap|Eden Sher}} (uncredited - seasons 1-2)
"Shining Star" performed{{nbsp}}by {{nowrap|Agnes Shin}} (season 3-present) |first_aired = {{Start date|2015|1|18}} |last_aired = {{End date|present}} |num_seasons = 3 |num_episodes = 56 |list_episodes = List of Star vs. the Forces of Evil episodes |executive_producer = {{plainlist| * Daron Nefcy * Dave Wasson (co-executive, season 1) * Jordana Arkin (co-executive, season 1) }} |producer = {{plainlist| * Aaron Hammersley (supervising) * Dominic Bisignano (supervising) }} |website = http://disneyxd.disney.com/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil }} '''''Star vs. the Forces of Evil''''' is an American [[Animated series|animated]] [[television series]] created by Daron Nefcy and developed by Jordana Arkin and [[Dave Wasson]], which airs on [[Disney XD]]. The first Disney XD series created by a woman, and the third overall for [[Disney Television Animation]] (following ''[[Pepper Ann]]'' and ''[[Doc McStuffins]]''), it follows the adventures of Star Butterfly (voiced by [[Eden Sher]]), the turbulent young heir to the royal throne in the dimension of Mewni, who is sent to Earth so she can complete her education and learn to be a worthy princess, and Marco Diaz ([[Adam McArthur]]), a human teenager who becomes her roommate and best friend, as they live their daily lives, and go on adventures in other dimensions.{{cite web|url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/tv/disney-tries-something-new-with-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-a-woman-creator-102477.html|title=Disney Tries Something New With ‘Star Vs. The Forces of Evil’: A Woman Creator|author=|date=|work=Cartoon Brew|accessdate=July 6, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://thewaltdisneycompany.com/blog/women-animation-host-‘star-vs-forces-evil’-panel|first=Robert|last=Koontz|date=March 25, 2015|work=Disney Post|publisher = Disney|title=Women In Animation Host ‘Star vs. The Forces of Evil’ Panel|accessdate=July 29, 2015}} ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' typically follows a format of two 11-minutes long independent "segments" per episode. The first episode aired on January 18, 2015 on [[Disney Channel]] and became the most-watched animated series debut in Disney XD’s history. The fourth season is to premiere in 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2018/07/sdcc-2018-watch-disneys-first-looks-at-new-episode.html|title=SDCC 2018: Watch Disney's First Looks at New Episodes of 'Star vs. the Forces of Evil' and Big City Greens'|first=Alexis|last=Gunderson|date=July 19, 2018|work=Paste Magazine|accessdate=August 13, 2018}} ==Plot== {{Main|List of Star vs. the Forces of Evil characters}} Star Butterfly is a [[Magical girl|magical princess]] from the dimension of Mewni, and the heir to the royal throne of the Butterfly Kingdom. As per tradition, she is given the family heirloom wand on her 14th birthday. After she accidentally sets fire to the family castle, her parents King River and Queen Moon Butterfly decide that a safer option is to send her to Earth as a [[foreign exchange student]], so she can continue her magic training there. She befriends Marco Diaz and lives with his family while attending Echo Creek Academy. Going in a series of misadventures using "dimensional scissors" that can open [[Portals in fiction|portals]], Star and Marco must deal with everyday school life while protecting Star's wand from falling into the hands of Ludo, a villain from Mewni who commands a group of monsters. Besides also dealing with her ex-boyfriend Tom, in Season 3, Star goes up against more serious villains like Toffee and Meteora Butterfly while uncovering the mystery behind her relative Eclipsa Butterfly. ==Background and production== Nefcy said she originally created Star as a girl who wanted to be a [[magical girl]] like ''[[Sailor Moon (character)|Sailor Moon]]'', and Marco as a boy who was obsessed with ''[[Dragon Ball Z]]'' and karate; they would be enemies instead of friends. In this earlier version, Star did not have any actual magical powers; she instead would approach and solve problems primarily through the force of her determination alone.{{cite web|url=http://blogs.disney.com/insider/2015/07/20/creator-daron-nefcy-guides-us-through-tonights-star-studded-episode-of-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil/|title=Creator Daron Nefcy Guides Us Through Tonight’s Star-Studded Episode of Star Vs. the Forces of Evil|date=July 20, 2015|work=Disney Insider Blog|accessdate=November 5, 2015}}{{Cite web|last=Rutherford|first=Kristen|title=Interview: Daron Nefcy of Disney’s Star vs. the Forces of Evil|url=http://nerdist.com/interview-daron-nefcy-of-disneys-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil/|work=[[Nerdist Industries|Nerdist]]|date=March 26, 2015 }} Nefcy began pitching the show when she was in her third year of college, when Cartoon Network was actively soliciting the creation of pilots for prospective new shows. Nefcy originally placed Star in the fourth grade, reflecting on a time in her own childhood when she held a self-described obsession with the animated series ''[[Sailor Moon (anime)|Sailor Moon]]''. However, Nefcy later adjusted the character's age to fourteen during the time she made her series proposition to Disney.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jim-hill/how-comic-con-helped-crea_b_5989262.html|title=How Comic-Con Helped Create Fans for Disney XD's ''Star vs. The Forces of Evil'' Six Months Before Its First Episode Airs - Jim Hill|author=|date=|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=July 17, 2015}} An executive at that time made the suggestion for Star to have actual magical powers. Nefcy worked this concept into the show's current iteration, along with the idea of different dimensions as show locations, the framing device of Star being a foreign exchange student, and the plot aspects relating to Star being a princess and the subsequent consequences of her royal birthright. Nefcy said that the overall concept has evolved over about six years. In addition to ''[[Sailor Moon (anime)|Sailor Moon]]'' and ''[[Dragon Ball Z]]'', Nefcy has said that she had heavy influence in her youth from the animated Japanese shows ''[[Magic Knight Rayearth]]'', ''[[Revolutionary Girl Utena]]'' and ''[[Unico]]'', the last of which featured a pink unicorn. She also cited shows unrelated to Japanese animation such as ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'', and was influenced by independent comic series such as ''[[Scott Pilgrim]]'' and ''The Dungeon''. With regards to the development of more strong female characters, Nefcy said that she "looked at TV over the years and I have had to go to Japan when I was younger to find the cartoons that had the characters that I wanted to see. It was always a question of 'Well, why isn't that on TV in the U.S.?'" One of the concepts she likes about the show is that it doesn't make high school the most important experience for teenagers. She also likes that Star does her own thing instead of being concerned about fitting in. Nefcy did not want the gimmick about keeping the magic powers a secret from others as typical of magical girl shows, so she had the students already know about it and Marco's parents as well. She also portrays Star as not really a superhero as she does not specifically go after super-villains except when they attack her, and that she doesn't really save people. Nefcy said that the episodes balance comedy and drama: "we really want our characters to feel like teenagers and have them going through the normal emotions that teenagers go through, but in this magical setting." Storyboarding and design are done in Los Angeles. In describing the process, Nefcy said that the show is storyboard-driven, with each episode mapped out by the storyboard artists. The storyboarders also do the writing, taking a two-page outline and turning it into a full script. A storyboard for 11 minutes would require about 2000 drawings to be done in a six-week period.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/disney-animator-shares-best-and-worst-parts-of-her-job-2015-3|title=Disney animator shares best and worst parts of her job|work=[[Business Insider]]|first=Jacquelyn|last=Smith|date=March 24, 2015|accessdate=July 22, 2015}} After pre-production in the US, the first season animation was done at [[Mercury Filmworks]] in Ottawa, Canada. Mercury had also done ''[[Wander Over Yonder]]'' and the ''[[Mickey Mouse (TV series)|Mickey Mouse]]'' series. For the rest of first season, the animation was done in the Philippines. The second season was animated by Sugarcube and [[Rough Draft Studios]], both located in South Korea.{{cite tweet | user=daronnefcy | author=Daron Nefcy | number=679476188838903808 | title=@chuck_kopsho nope, now it's Sugarcube and RDK | date=December 22, 2015 | accessdate=August 19, 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://daronnefcy.com/post/135744482230/recently-i-got-the-wonderful-opportunity-to-visit|title=- Recently I got the wonderful opportunity to visit...|first=Daron|last=Nefcy | date=December 22, 2015 | work=daronnefcy.com|accessdate=February 26, 2017}} The theme song was done by Brad Breeck, who also did ''[[Gravity Falls]]''{{'}} opening theme; Nefcy said: "when we were listening to it we didn't know, because we just listened [[Blind experiment|blind]]". Brian Kim was chosen among a group of about ten people as the show's composer.{{cite web|url=http://comicbook.com/2015/03/25/get-a-little-weird-and-wild-with-daron-nefcys-star-vs-the-forces/|title=Get a Little Weird and Wild with Daron Nefcy's Star Vs. The Forces Of Evil on Disney XD|first=Lucas |last=Siegel|date=March 25, 2015|work=Comicbook.com|accessdate=July 17, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.brianhkim.com/starvstheforces.html|title=Brian H. Kim|author=|date=|work=brianhkim.com|accessdate=September 22, 2015}} Kim describes the music for each dimension as having a different sound and relating it to indie rock in Los Angeles.{{cite tweet | author=Brian H. Kim | user= BrianWithAnH | number=557041149689339905 | date=January 18, 2015 | title=We wanted the different dimensions to have a different "sound." Echo Creek is very laid-back LA indie rock. #StarVsTheForcesOfEvil | accessdate=October 15, 2016 }} The show was initially scheduled to premiere on [[Disney Channel]] after being greenlighted in March 2013, for a premiere in the Fall of 2014, before being switched over to Disney XD.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2013/03/disney-channel-greenlights-animated-series-about-magical-princess-from-young-creator-447677/|title=Disney Channel Greenlights Animated Series About Magical Princess From Young Creator|author=Nellie Andreeva|date=March 7, 2013|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=February 17, 2015}} However, on February 23, 2018, it was announced that the show would be moving to Disney Channel for its fourth season.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/02/disney-channel-renews-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-announces-amphibia-owl-house-1202300438/|title=Disney Channel Launching Toon Series 'Amphibia' & 'The Owl House', Renews 'Star Vs. The Forces of Evil' For Season 4|first=Erik|last=Pedersen|date=February 23, 2018|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=February 23, 2018}} ==Promotion and release== The show's title sequence was promoted at [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con 2014]] six months prior to its scheduled broadcast premiere. As a result, the footage was uploaded by fans to YouTube who then started generating fan art and fan fiction. The first episode premiered on Disney Channel in January 2015. The positive reaction on social media prompted Disney XD to order a second season of the series in February 2015, six weeks ahead of its launch of the series on Disney XD in March.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2015/02/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-renewed-season-two-disney-xd-1201371982/|title=Disney XD Orders Season 2 Of ‘Star Vs. The Forces of Evil’ Ahead Of Its Launch - Deadline|author=The Deadline Team|date=|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=July 17, 2015}} Disney sitcom actors [[Olivia Holt]] and [[Kelli Berglund]] participated in promoting the series the weeks before its Disney XD premiere, with Holt dressing up as Star.{{cite web|url=http://video.disney.com/watch/disneyxd-behind-the-scenes-with-olivia-holt-5118985a81549b825266b374|title=Behind the Scenes with Olivia Holt - Star vs. the Forces of Evil - Disney Video|author=|date=|work=Disney Video|accessdate=July 31, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://video.disney.com/watch/disneyxd-puppies-511325df60dcee09a9b023df|title=Puppies - Star vs. the Forces of Evil - Disney Video|author=|date=|work=Disney Video|accessdate=July 31, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316192437/http://video.disney.com/watch/disneyxd-puppies-511325df60dcee09a9b023df|archivedate=March 16, 2015|df=mdy-all}} The second season premiered on July 11, 2016,{{cite web | url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-season-2-melissa-rauch-mayim-bialik-1201783224/ | title=‘Big Bang Theory’ Stars to Guest on Disney XD’s ‘Star vs. the Forces of Evil’ | publisher=Variety | date=May 26, 2016 | accessdate=May 26, 2016 | author=McClendon, Lamarco}} The show's third season was ordered ahead in March 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/disney-xd-orders-pair-original-872355|title=Disney XD Orders Pair of Original Animated Series (Exclusive)|author=Bryn Elise Sandberg|date=March 4, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=March 4, 2016}} It premiered on July 15, 2017 with a two-hour long television movie entitled "The Battle for Mewni" and consisted of the first four episodes.{{cite web|url=http://comicbook.com/tv-shows/2017/05/26/exclusive-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-tv-movie-premieres-july/|title=Exclusive: Star Vs. The Forces Of Evil TV Movie Coming This Summer|first=Joseph |last=Schmidt | date=May 26, 2017 | work=Comicbook.com | accessdate=May 27, 2017}}{{cite tweet| user=daronnefcy | author=Daron Nefcy | number=868208896199974912/|title=I just want to be clear that the movie is the 1st 4 episodes of S3 played together. It will play like a movie but it is the premiere of S3. | date=May 26, 2017 | accessdate=May 26, 2017 }} A live chat featuring Star and Marco was aired on Disney XD on July 17.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vo0hnxp4RdI|title=Star and Marco Live Chat - Star vs. the Forces of Evil - Disney XD|first=|last=Disney XD|date=July 16, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=October 31, 2018|via=YouTube}} The remaining third-season episodes started airing on November 6, 2017.{{Citation|mode=cs1|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9avS6Lb9zTk|title=This Season in Mewni...|publisher=Disney-ABC Television Group|via=YouTube|accessdate=July 18, 2017|date=July 18, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://comicbook.com/tv-shows/2017/05/26/exclusive-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-tv-movie-premieres-july/|title=Exclusive: Star vs. the Forces of Evil TV Movie Coming This Summer|first=Joseph |last=Schmidt | date=May 26, 2017 | work=ComicBook.com | accessdate=May 27, 2017}} A fourth season was also ordered ahead of the third season premiere.{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/disney-xd-renews-al-yankovics-milo-murphys-law-eden-shers-star-forces-evil-981534|title=Disney XD Renews Al Yankovic's 'Milo Murphy's Law,' Eden Sher's 'Star vs. The Forces of Evil' (Exclusive)|first=Kimberly |last=Nordyke|date=February 28, 2017|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=February 28, 2017}} ===International=== ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' premiered in Canada on [[Family Chrgd|the DHX-owned Disney XD]] on April 6, 2015,{{cite press release|url=http://www.awn.com/news/star-vs-forces-evil-debuts-april-6|title=‘Star Vs. The Forces Of Evil’ Debuts on April 6|date=March 31, 2015|location=Toronto|last=Wolfe|first=Jennifer|work=Animation World Network|accessdate=August 19, 2015}} and was later moved to [[Disney XD (Canada)|the Corus-owned Disney XD]] on December 1.{{cite web|title=Disney XD|url=http://www.disneychannel.ca/blog/disney-xd|website=disneychannel.ca Buzz Blog|publisher=Corus Entertainment|date=November 1, 2015|accessdate=November 2, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117020552/http://www.disneychannel.ca/blog/disney-xd|archivedate=November 17, 2015|df=mdy-all}} The series premiered on Disney XD channels in the [[Disney XD (UK and Ireland)|United Kingdom and Ireland]] on April 16, 2015,{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7rKSN0p95qw|title=Disney XD UK Easter Continuity 2015|author=VGX / TV Holidays|date=April 8, 2015|work=YouTube|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}{{better source|date=August 2015|reason=unofficial video clip on YouTube}} in [[Disney XD (Australia)|Australia]] on August 3,{{cite web|url=http://community.foxtel.com.au/t5/Foxtel-Blog/New-on-Foxtel-in-August-200-shows-including-Texas-Rising-Rogue/ba-p/85411|title=New on Foxtel in August: 200+ shows including Texas Rising, Rogue and 7 Days In Hell|last=P|first=Chuck|work=The Green Room|publisher=Foxtel|date=July 31, 2015|accessdate=August 19, 2015}} and in the [[Disney XD (Africa)|Middle East and Africa]] on October 5.{{cite web|url=http://www.samdb.co.za/blogs/blog/2015/08/31/disney-xd-programming-highlights-for-october-2015/|title=Disney XD Programming Highlights For October 2015|date=August 31, 2015|last=Germishuys|first=Andrew|work=South African Movie Database|accessdate=October 3, 2015}} It also premiered on November 8 on [[Disney Channel (Asia)|Disney Channel]] in Southeast Asia.{{cite web|url=http://video.disney.ph/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-premiere|title=Star Vs The Forces Of Evil Premiere|work=Disney Philippines|accessdate=November 5, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://video.disney.sg/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-premiere|title=Star Vs The Forces Of Evil Premiere|work=Disney Singapore|accessdate=December 10, 2015}} The series premiered on March 6, 2016, as ''Star Butterfly'' in French on [[Disney La Chaîne]] in Canada.{{cite web|url=http://www.disneylachaine.ca/videos/star-butterfly|title=Star Butterfly|author=|date=|work=La chaîne Disney|accessdate=March 4, 2016}} The show premiered on November 2 on [[Disney XD (Italy)|Disney XD]] in Italy, and on [[Disney Channel (Italy)|Disney Channel]] on November 2, 2016.{{cite web|url=http://disneyxd.disney.it/video/marco-e-star-dal-7-novembre|title=Marco e Star - Dal 7 Novembre | language=Italian | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230045523/http://disneyxd.disney.it/video/marco-e-star-dal-7-novembre | archive-date=2016-12-30 | deadurl=yes | access-date=November 19, 2017}} ==Episodes== {{Main|List of Star vs. the Forces of Evil episodes|l1=List of Star vs. the Forces of Evil episodes}} {{:List of Star vs. the Forces of Evil episodes}} ==Reception== ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' has received positive reviews by critics. Kevin Johnson of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the pilot episode a B+, saying that the show was something children could have a lot of fun with, noting how the show follows current trends in western animation "towards large-eyed characters and quirky visual trends". Johnson stated that ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' "excels on wild, silly, and clever set-pieces to bring the laughs and action", but expected that adult viewers won't get much out of it.{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/star-vs-forces-evil-star-comes-earthparty-pony-214001|title=''Star Vs. The Forces Of Evil'': "Star Comes To Earth/Party With APony"[sic]|publisher=''[[The A.V. Club]]''|last=Johnson|first=Kevin|date=January 18, 2015}} Furthermore, the premiere of ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' became the most-watched animated series debut in Disney XD’s history.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/tv/news/disney-xd-sets-animated-ratings-high-with-premiere-of-star-vs-the-forces-of-evil-1201467036/|title=Disney XD Sets Animated Ratings High with Premiere of ‘Star vs. the Forces of Evil’|publisher=''[[Variety.com]]''|last=Kissell|first=Rick|date=April 6, 2015}} Following the end of the second season, Disney XD announced it had ordered a fourth season of the show, and that in 2016, ''Star'' and another animated show ''[[Milo Murphy's Law]]'' had reached over 100 million consumer views combined across its media platforms. In reviewing episodes from the first season, Marcy Cook of ''[[The Mary Sue]]'' described the show as a blend of others such as ''[[Invader Zim]]'' and a sanitized ''[[Ren & Stimpy]]'', with great appeal to tween and teen girls as well some laugh out loud moments for adults. She said, "[I]t's really cool to see a girl who is into cuteness and rainbows also kick-ass and enjoy it". Cook was bothered by the short episodes that made the plot seem rushed or underdeveloped. Cook was bugged by Marco's [[retcon]]ned personality from the pilot episode where he was a safety conscious kid to the series where he was a martial arts fight seeker.{{cite web|url=http://www.themarysue.com/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil/|title=You Should Give Star Vs The Forces of Evil a Try|author=|date=|work=themarysue.com|accessdate=July 18, 2015}} Caitlin Donovan of entertainment website Epicstream listed it among her top 10 animated series of 2015. She found the first few episodes to be "a little rough for me, like the show was trying too hard to be funny and weird", but that the show got better with character development and relationship building, with "a really dramatic, high-tension finale to the first season".{{cite web|url=http://epicstream.com/featureslist/Top-10-Animated-Series-of-2015/2|title=Epicstream|author=|date=|work=epicstream.com|accessdate=March 26, 2016}} ===Awards and nominations=== The episode "Party with a Pony" was showcased in the [[Annecy International Animated Film Festival]] in June 2015.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/festivals/annecy-animation-matt-groening-simpsons-1201514966/|title=Annecy Animation Festival hosts toon legends - Variety|author=Ellen Wolff|date=|work=Variety|accessdate=July 22, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.annecy.org/programme/index:film-20152012|title=Annecy > Programme > Index|author=CITIA|date=|work=annecy.org|accessdate=July 6, 2015}} {|class="wikitable sortable" |- !Year !Award !Category !Nominee !Result !Ref |- |rowspan="2"| 2015 | [[Annecy International Animated Film Festival]] | TV Series | Episode: "Party with a Pony" | {{nom}} | |- | 5th Annual BTVA Voice Acting Awards | Best Female Vocal Performance in a Television Series in a Supporting Role | [[Dee Dee Rescher]] as Miss Skullnick | {{nom}} | {{cite web|url=https://www.behindthevoiceactors.com/btva-awards/2015/television/|title=BTVA Voice Acting Awards 2015 – Television|author=|date=|website=Behind The Voice Actors|accessdate=October 31, 2018}} |- |rowspan="8"| 2016 |rowspan="3"| [[43rd Annie Awards]] | Best Animated Television / Broadcast Production for Children | ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'', Episode: "Blood Moon Ball" | {{nom}} | {{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/2016-annie-award-winners-862117/item/editorial-an-animated-television-broadcast-862114|title=2016 Annie Award Winners - Hollywood Reporter|author=Carolyn Giardina|date=February 6, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=March 4, 2016}} |- | Voice Acting in an Animated Television/Broadcast Production | [[Alan Tudyk]] as Ludo, Episode: Compilation from Series | {{nom}} | |- | Editorial in an Animated Television/Broadcast Production | Ted Supa, Episode: "Storm the Castle" | {{nom}} | |- | rowspan="5"| 6th Annual BTVA Voice Acting Awards | Best Male Lead Vocal Performance in a Television Series | [[Adam McArthur]] as Marco Diaz |{{nom}} | {{cite web|url=https://www.behindthevoiceactors.com/btva-awards/2016/television/|title=BTVA Voice Acting Awards 2016 – Television |author=|date=|website=Behind The Voice Actors|accessdate=October 31, 2018}} |- | Best Female Lead Vocal Performance in a Television Series | [[Eden Sher]] as Star Butterfly | {{nom}} | |- | Best Female Vocal Performance in a Television Series in a Supporting Role | [[Jenny Slate]] as Pony Head | {{nom}} | |- | Best Female Vocal Performance in a Television Series in a Guest Role | [[Yvette Nicole Brown]] as Brigid | {{nom}} | |- | Best Vocal Ensemble in a Television Series | ''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' | {{nom}} | |- | 2017 | 7th Annual BTVA Voice Acting Awards | Best Female Lead Vocal Performance in a Television Series | [[Eden Sher]] as Star Butterfly | {{nom}} | {{cite web|url=https://www.behindthevoiceactors.com/btva-awards/2017/television/|title=BTVA Voice Acting Awards 2017–Television|author=|date=|website=Behind The Voice Actors|accessdate=October 31, 2018}} |} ==Other media== A comic book series titled ''Deep Trouble'' was written by storyboarder Zach Marcus and illustrated by character designer Devin Taylor, both of whom are part of the ''Star'' crew. They have been released monthly by Joe Books starting in September 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.laughingplace.com/w/news/2016/05/26/star-vs-forces-evil-season-2-kick-off-july-11-disney-xd/|title="Star vs. The Forces of Evil" Season 2 to Kick Off July 11 on Disney XD - LaughingPlace.com|first=Laughing Place Disney|last=Newsdesk|date=May 26, 2016|website=laughingplace.com|accessdate=May 27, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://daronnefcy.com/post/146114400471/this-is-the-1st-cover-of-the-new-star-original|title=- This is the 1st cover of the new Star original...|author=|date=|website=daronnefcy|accessdate=May 27, 2017}} A ''Cinestory'' comic was also developed and released.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Disney-Star-Forces-Cinestory-Comic/dp/1988032415|title=Disney Star vs. The Forces of Evil Cinestory Comic|first=|last=Disney|date=May 31, 2016|publisher=Joe Books Inc.|accessdate=May 27, 2017|via=Amazon}} The book ''Star and Marco's Guide to Mastering Every Dimension'', authored by [[Amber Benson]] and supervising producer Dominic Bisignano, was released on March 7, 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Forces-Marcos-Guide-Mastering-Dimension/dp/1484774191|title=Star vs. the Forces of Evil Star and Marco's Guide to Mastering Every Dimension|first1=Amber|last1=Benson|first2=Dominic|last2=Bisignano|date=March 7, 2017|publisher=Disney Press|accessdate=May 27, 2017|via=Amazon}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/disney-xd-renews-al-yankovics-milo-murphys-law-eden-shers-star-forces-evil-981534|title=Disney XD Renews Al Yankovic's 'Milo Murphy's Law,' Eden Sher's 'Star vs. The Forces of Evil' (Exclusive)|author=|date=|website=hollywoodreporter.com|accessdate=May 27, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= }} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://disneyxd.disney.com/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil}} * {{Official website|http://www.disneyabcpress.com/disneyxd/shows/star-vs-the-forces-of-evil/|''Star vs. the Forces of Evil'' Disney Press website}} * {{IMDb title|2758770}} * {{bcdb|Walt_Disney_Studios/Television/Star_Vs__The_Forces_of_Evil/|Star Vs. {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} '''Tam''' (or '''Tamas''') '''Lin''' (also called '''Tamlane''', '''Tamlin''', '''Tambling''', '''Tomlin''', '''Tam Lien''', '''Tam-a-Line''', '''Tam Lyn''', or '''Tam Lane''') is a character in a [[legend]]ary [[ballad]] originating from the Scottish Borders. It is also associated with a [[Reel (dance)|reel]] of the same name, also known as the Glasgow Reel. The story revolves around the rescue of Tam Lin by his true love from the [[Queen of the Fairies]]. The motif of capturing a person by holding him through all forms of [[Transformation chase|transformation]] is found throughout Europe in [[Folklore|folktale]]s.<ref name=Child>{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/englishscottishp02chil#page/334/mode/2up|editor-last=Child|editor-first=Francis James|title=Tam Lin|work=English and Scottish Popular Ballads|volume=I Part 2|pages=335-358|publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|Houghton Mifflin and Company]]|location=Boston|year=1890|accessdate=2017-11-19}}</ref><ref name=Sacred>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/eng/child/ch039.htmm|title=Tam Lin|work=The English and Scottish Popular Ballads|publisher=[[Internet Sacred Text Archive]]|year=2011|accessdate=2017-11-19}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
The story has been adapted into numerous stories, songs and films.
==Synopsis== [[File:Carterhaugh.jpg|thumb|[[Carterhaugh]], near the confluence of the [[Yarrow Water]] and the [[Ettrick Water]]]] Most variants begin with the warning that Tam Lin collects either a possession or the [[virginity]] of any maiden who passes through the forest of [[Carterhaugh]]. When a young woman, usually called Janet or Margaret, goes to Carterhaugh and plucks a double rose, Tam appears and asks her why she has come without his leave and taken what is his. She states that she owns Carterhaugh because her father has given it to her.<ref name=Fresno>{{cite web|url=http://www.fresnostate.edu/folklore/ballads/C039.html|last=Waltz|first=Robert B.|last2=Engle|first2=David G.|title=Tam Lin|work=Folklore The Traditional Ballad Index: An Annotated Bibliography of the Folk Songs of the English-Speaking World|publisher=[[California State University, Fresno]]|year=2012|accessdate=2017-11-19}}</ref>
In most variants, Janet then goes home and discovers that she is pregnant; some variants pick up the story at this point. When asked about her condition, she declares that her baby's father is an [[elf]] whom she will not forsake. In some versions, she is informed of a herb that will induce abortion; in all the variants, when she returns to Carterhaugh and picks a plant, either the same roses as on her earlier visit or the herb, Tam reappears and challenges her action.<ref name=Child />
She asks him whether he was ever human, either after that reappearance or, in some versions, immediately after their first meeting resulted in her pregnancy. He reveals that he was a mortal man, who, falling from his horse, was caught and captured by the Queen of Fairies. Every seven years, the fairies give one of their people as a [[teind]] ([[tithe]]) to [[Hell]] and Tam fears he will become the tithe that night, which is [[Halloween|Hallowe'en]]. He is to ride as part of a company of elven knights. Janet will recognise him by the white horse upon which he rides and by other signs. He instructs her to rescue him by pulling him down from the white horse - so Janet "catches" him this time - and holds him tightly. He warns her that the fairies will attempt to make her drop him by [[Transformation chase|turning him]] into all manner of beasts (see [[Proteus]]), but that he will do her no harm. When he is finally turned into a burning coal, she is to throw him into a well, whereupon he will reappear as a naked man, and she must hide him. Janet does as she is asked and wins her knight. The Queen of Fairies is angry but acknowledges defeat.<ref name=Fresno /><ref name=Child /><ref name=Fresno />
In different variations, Tam Lin is reportedly the grandson of the Laird of [[Roxburgh]], the Laird of [[Foulis Castle|Foulis]], the [[Lord Forbes|Earl]] of [[Castle Forbes|Forbes]], or the [[Earl of Moray|Earl of Murray]]. His name also varies between versions (Tam Lin being the most common) as Tom Line, Tomlin, Young Tambling, Tam-a-line and Tamlane.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/stream/balladsweirdwond00choprich#page/n115/mode/2up|last=Chope|first=R.P.|title=Tamlane|work=Ballads Weird and Wonderful|pages=53-60|publisher=Ballantyne, Hanson & Co.|year=1911|accessdate=2017-11-19}}</ref><ref name= JacobsMore />
==Variants== The ballad dates to at least as early as 1549 (the publication date of ''[[The Complaynt of Scotland]]'' that mentions "The Tayl of the [[Yogh|Ȝ]]ong Tamlene" ('The Tale of the Young Tamelene') among a long list of medieval romances).<ref name=Child /><ref>The Complaynt of Scotland, c. vi., ed. J. A. H. Murray, E.E.T.S., p.68 (excerpted in: {{cite book|last=Ker|first=W. P.|authorlink=William Paton Ker|title=Epic and romance: essays on medieval literature|publisher=Macmillan|year=1922|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1yaFAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA389|page=389}})</ref>
There have been several interpretations of the Tam Lin story:
* [[Francis James Child]] collected fourteen variants in ''The English and Scottish Popular Ballads''.<ref name=Child /> (Another Child ballad, ''[[Burd Ellen and Young Tamlane]]'', has no connection with this ballad except for the similarity of the heroes' names.) * [[Joseph Jacobs]] included a variant, "Tamlane", in ''More English Fairy Tales''.<ref name="JacobsMore" /> * [[John Myers Myers]] tells a variant in Silverlock. * [[Michael Drayton]]'s narrative poem ''Nimphidia'' (1627) includes the character who goes by the name Tomalin. In the poem he is a vassal and kinsman of [[Oberon]], King of the Fairies.
==Motifs== Child took the threat to take out Tam Lin's eyes as a common [[Scottish folklore|folklore]] precaution against mortals who could see fairies, in the tales of [[fairy ointment]]. [[Joseph Jacobs]] interpreted it as rather a reversal of the usual practice; the Queen of Faerie would have kept him from seeing the human woman who rescued him.<ref name=JacobsMore/>
In some variants, "[[Hind Etin]]" has verses identical to this for the first meeting between the hero and heroine.<ref name=Child />{{rp|340}}
